content: Each year, Congress funds the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to renew over 2.1 million Section 8 vouchers, also known as Housing Choice Vouchers. These vouchers are federally funded and administered by local public housing authorities to provide rental subsidies for low-income families in the private market. Section 8 vouchers are rental subsidies for low-income families administered by public housing authorities. The cost of a voucher is based on the difference between actual rent and a payment standard, and 30% of the tenant's income. This cost fluctuates with changes in tenant incomes, rents, and payment standards. The Section 8 voucher program provides rental subsidies for low-income families based on the difference between actual rent and a payment standard, as well as 30% of the tenant's income.
